11473 "Europe and Central Asia" "The project sponsor is Dr. Grigory Roytberg: the founder and President of the company which has been in operation since 1990.  In addition to being a successful and respected entrepreneur
column2: Dr. Roytberg is also a well published
column3: internationally known cardiologist and Head of the Department of Family Medicine at the Russian State Medical University.  Dr. Roytberg is also a member of the Russian Academy of Medical Science and an Honored Physician of the Russian Federation. The sponsor
column4: directly or indirectly
column5: controls the company." "2008-01-10" "2008-02-21" "Not found or country name unknown" "The project cost is estimated at Rb2.5 billion ($96.7 million) of which IFC proposes to finance up to $50 million through a combination of debt for its own account and equity.  The exact balance between IFC debt and equity investments will be determined upon finalization of the financing plan." 11598 NA "Opportunity International
column2: Inc
column3: (Opportunity) is a tax-exempt
column4: publicly supported Christian-based corporation whose purpose is to create employment and improve income for the poor by assisting in the establishment of small and micro businesses in developing countries. Opportunitys programs are financed through direct solicitation of funds from individuals
column5: corporations
column6: foundations
column7: churches and government grants. Over the past 30 years
column8: OI has developed over 50 microfinance institutions in 25 countries in Latin America
column9: Asia
column10: Europe and Africa. Opportunity now servesover 907
column11: 000credit clients annually and expects to be serving 1 million by 2007
column12: and 2 million by 2010. If clients served through deposit and insurance products are included
column13: the number of clients currently served by OI already reaches beyond 1.5 million of the worlds poor. OIs strategy is to effectively combine significant outreach to the lowest level of the microfinance sector with financial sustainability. Building on its successes
column14: particularly in Eastern Europe
column15: OI seeks to replicate this model widely in Africa. In June 2000
column16: Opportunity incorporated Opportunity Transformation Investments
column17: inc (OTI)
column18: which invests in and holds ownership positions in MFIs as they convert from NGOs to commercial MFIs or microfinance banks. OTI has majority equity positions in Opportunity International-Sinapi Aba Savings & Loans (Ghana)
column19: Opportunity International Bank Malawi (Malawi)
column20: Banco Oportunidade de Mozambique (Mozambique)
column21: OI-WEDCO (Kenya)
column22: Opportunity International Bank Rwanda (Rwanda)
column23: Opportunity Finance (South Africa)
column24: PSHM (Albania)
column25: Opportunity Bank Montenegro (Montenegro)
column26: and Opportunity Bank Serbia (Serbia). In addition to these majority holdings
column27: OTI has minority holdings in Opportunity Microfinance Bank (Philippines)
column28: S.C. Opportunity Microcredit Romania s.R.L. (Romania)
column29: Development Finance Equity Partners GMBH (Switzerland)
column30: Zambuko Trust Limited (Zimbabwe)
column31: and Faulu (Uganda)." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "The proposed program entails up to: - $4 million in IFC equity investments in OTI companies; - $2 million TA facility to provide capacity building support for the investee MFIs; - $9 million regional IFC stand-by credit facility
column32: with some form of OI guarantee
column33: to support the portfolio growth of OIs network MFIs." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/34cc2a69442a975f852576ba000e2972?OpenDocument"

22497 NA "Created in 2001
column2: Ideal started operations providing funding for universities through acquisitions of university-owned tuition receivables. In late 2006
column3: the company launched its student lending product called Pravaler to provide students access to loans to pay for tuition at private universities. Today
column4: the company is the largest private provider of student loans in Brazil
column5: working with 110 universities in 14 states.   Some of Ideals shareholders include its CEO as well as some of Brazils leading investment firms." "2009-10-09" "2009-11-09" "Not found or country name unknown" "As Ideal Invest plans to accelerate the growth of its student loan program
column6: it has asked IFC to provide a credit enhancement to the senior securities in the form of an irrevocable guarantee to buy mezzanine securities in an amount up to R$60 million. IFC will be committed to buy mezzanine securities in case certain events occur and the FIDC is not able to make certain payments to senior investors. Before activating IFCs guarantee
column7: Ideal will maintain a minimum subordination level by purchasing subordinated securities. Initially
column8: the junior securities purchased by Ideal and IFCs guarantee to buy mezzanine securities will provide the senior securities with sufficient subordination." 23915 "East Asia and the Pacific" "NSCC is a foreign joint venture owned 65% by NM Cement Company Ltd. (NMCC or the sponsor) and the 35% by Vietnam Cement Industry Corporation (VICEM
column2: and together with NMCC
column3: the sponsors)
column4: a state-owned cement holding company.  NMCC is a Japanese joint-venture owned 70% by Taiheiyo Cement Corp. (Taiheiyo) and 30% by Mitsubishi Materials Corp. (MMC).   - Taiheiyo Cement:  Taiheiyo was formed in 1998 through the merger of Chichibu Cement and Nihon Cement
column5: and is today the largest cement producer in Japan
column6: with a 35% market share. It is also the worlds seventh largest cement producer with an installed capacity of 51 million tpy.  It generates two-thirds of its sales from Japan
column7: 25% from North America
column8: and the remaining from Asia including China
column9: South Korea
column10: the Philippines and Vietnam. Taiheiyo currently consists of 327 subsidiaries and 153 affiliates organized into cement (62%)
column11: mineral resources (11%)
column12: environmental (7%)
column13: construction materials (10%)
column14: ceramics and electronics (8%)
column15: and other businesses. Taiheiyo is listed on Tokyo Stock Exchange and Fukuoka Stock Exchange in Japan. Its top ten shareholders are mostly Japanese financial institutions including The Master Trust Bank of Japan (trust account
column17: Japan Trustee Services Bank (trust account
column19: and Nippon Life Insurance Company (3.4%). For FY2007 ended March 31st 2007
column20: Taiheiyo reported sales of $7.96 billion
column21: net income of $206.7 million and total assets of $10.6 billion. According to the interim report
column22: by September 31st
column24: Taiheiyo reported sales of $3.8 billion and net income of $71 million.  - Mitsubishi Materials:  Founded in 1950
column25: MMC is a producer of industrial materials including fabricated metal products
column26: nonferrous metals
column27: cement and silicon. It is the second largest cement producer in Japan and approximately 14.4% of the companys revenues are derived from cement (volume of 13.9 million tpy). Besides NSCC
column28: it operates two cement plants outside of Japan
column29: one in Yantai
column30: China and one in California.  It is listed on Tokyo Stock Exchange and Osaka Security Exchange in Japan. In FY 2007 ended March 31st 2007
column31: MMC achieved revenues of $12.3 billion vs. $9.7 billion for FY2006. Net income during the period improved from $500 million in FY2006 to $604 million in FY2007.  Total assets stood at $15 billion. According to the interim report
column34: MMC   reported sales of $6.6 billion and net income of $333 million.  - VICEM:  VICEM is a large state-owned cement company and dominates the Vietnamese market with about 42% of production capacity and 38% of sales revenue in 2007. It has stakes in at least 20 large cement plants across the country
column35: including in partnership with the foreign players like Holcim
column36: Lafarge and Chinfon." "2008-11-28" "2008-12-23" "Not found or country name unknown" "The total project cost is estimated at $ 240 million
column37: consisting of:  - $168 million loan financing; and  - $72 million cash equity injection from sponsors.  The proposed IFC investment is an A Loan of up to $35 million and a B Loans of up to $33 million as part of a $168 million financing package. The remaining $100 million will consist of loans supported by sponsor guarantees
column38: including a $65 million subordinated loan from NMCC and a $35 million loan from JBIC supported by guarantee from the Government of Vietnam." 23938 NA "The Bank was founded as the Sugar Beet Cooperative Bank in 1953
column2: pooling the modest savings of the sugar beet growers who belonged to the cooperatives. Currently
column3: Sekerbank is a public company (approximately 30% free float on the Istanbul exchange) with the remainder owned 50/50 by the employee pension fund and Kazakhstan's Turan Alem Securities JSC
column4: a wholly owned subsidiary of Bank Turan Alem (BTA). The Bank has 214 branches in Turkey including rural areas in the central and eastern part of Turkey.  The current shareholder structure is Seker Bank Personnel Social Security Foundation (33.98%)
column5: Turan Alem Securities JSC (33.98%)
column6: beetroot cooperatives (2.01%) and the public (30.03%). Turan Alem Securities JSC is owned by Bank Turan Alem (or BTA). BTA is the second largest bank in Kazakhstan in terms of assets and equity.  BTAs assets represent about 22% of the total assets of the Kazakh banking sector. Privatized and merged from 2 state-owned banks in 1998
column7: BTA is now about 11% owned by a group of international financial institutions
column8: including IFC
column9: EBRD
column10: FMO
column11: and East Capital
column12: an international equity fund
column13: which has recently bought its stake from RZB. BTA issued issued the first RMBS in Kazakhstan in February 2007 with an amount of $153.6 million." 24051 "Latin America and the Caribbean" "The project sponsor is Inversiones Manuelita S.A. (Manuelita)
column2: the second largest sugar producer in Colombia with over 140 years of experience in sugar production.  Manuelita acquired a majority interest in Laredo in 1998 and devoted significant financial
column3: technical and managerial resources to turn the company into a highly productive and profitable enterprise.  Manuelita has a 79% interest in the company
column4: the balance being owned by individual investors and employees." "2006-11-08" "2006-11-22" "Peru" "The total project cost is estimated at $43 million over the period FY2005-2008.  The proposed IFC financing package comprises a corporate loan of up to $18 million." 24319 NA "ING is a major global financial services company
column2: providing a wide array of banking
column3: insurance and asset management services in over 50 countries. ING has 150 years of insurance expertise and has successfully launched insurance companies in North America
column4: Latin America
column5: Asia and Europe.  As of December 31
column7: ING Group had total assets of EUR 1
column8: 159 billion (ING Group comprises of ING Groep N.V.
column9: ING Verzekeringen N.V.
column10: ING Bank N.V. and all other subsidiaries). Its reported year end net profit was EUR 7.2 billion as compared with EUR 5.8 billion as of year end 2004.  INGs corporate structure includes six business lines: Insurance Americas
column11: Insurance Europe
column12: Insurance Asia/Pacific
column13: Wholesale Banking
column14: Retail Banking
column15: and ING Direct.  Both ING Group N.V. and ING Insurance N.V. are rated Aa3 by Moodys and AA- by Standard & Poors.  The corresponding ratings of ING Bank N.V. are AA and Aa2." "2007-02-15" "2007-06-20" "Not found or country name unknown" "Total projected project cost is estimated at Euro 222 million. The sponsors are listed below (with the relevant ownership percentage in parentheses):    - BHP Billiton (33.3%) BHP Billiton (ASX: BHP) is the worlds largest mining group based on market capitalization and operates as a diversified natural resources company with its headquarters in Melbourne
column7: Australia. IFC has targeted BHP Billiton to be one of its strategic global partners because of BHP Billitons ability to set high standards which can have a major influence on the industry as a whole. BHP Billiton considers its relationship with IFC and the World Bank as strategic to its activities in Africa. IFCs relationship with BHP Billiton in the mining sector includes Escondida in Chile and Mozal I & II in Mozambique. - Global Alumina (33.3%)    Global Alumina (GLA-U.To) has been the key project developer and negotiator of the various agreements with the Government until May 2007
column8: when 2/3rds of the project company was sold to BHP Billiton
column9: Dubai Aluminium Company Limited and Mubadala Development Company. Global Alumina was founded in 1999 with a vision to become the preferred low-cost alumina supplier to the independent aluminum industry by gaining first-mover advantage in the development of a domestic alumina refining industry in Guinea.  - Dubai Aluminium Company Limited (25.0%) Dubai Aluminium Company Limited (DUBAL) is 100% owned by the Dubai government. DUBAL was founded in 1979 and is the seventh largest producer of primary aluminum in the world with one of the largest single site aluminum smelter operations in the world located in Jebel Ali. This will be IFCs first engagement with DUBAL on a significant project financing opportunity.   - Mubadala Development Company (8.33%) The Mubadala Development Company (Mubadala) is a state owned company of the Abu Dhabi government. Mubadalas activities include: acquisition of new companies and strategic holdings in existing companies

column1: 24440 NA "SSgA is an investment management arm of State Street Bank and Trust Company
column2: a wholly-owned subsidiary of State Street Corporation (State Street)
column3: founded in 1792.  SSgA has pioneered the index management industry to become the largest manager of international indexed strategies worldwide.  As of June 2005
column4: SSgA had $1.4 trillion in total assets under management including over $100 billion as sustainability oriented investments.  Rexiter is a London-based investment management company with over $5 billion assets under management.  It was formed in 1997 by State Street and an established team of emerging markets professionals and currently majority owned by State Street Global Alliance (Alliance)
column5: a joint entity of State Street and ABP
column6: one of the world's largest pension funds.  Rexiter follows a proactive and disciplined investment approach
column7: based on fundamental analysis of countries and securities
column8: in both asset allocation and stock selection. Innovest is an internationally recognized research and advisory firm specializing in analysis of the impact of companies' sustainability performance on their competitiveness and profitability.  Founded in 1995
column9: Innovest currently has over $1.1 billion under global advisory mandates with leading asset management companies on the market.  State Street Global Alliance holds a minority stake in Innovest. 24460 NA "The project has been developed by IFC
column2: the participant banks
column3: and the Social Security National Investment Trust (SSNIT) as the first and only participant investor to date.  At this stage the Participating Banks consist of Ecobank Ghana (EBG)
column4: Fidelity Bank
column5: Ghana Home Loans (GHL)
column6: HFC Bank and Merchant Bank Ghana (MBG).  All are committed to developing their retail banking businesses
column7: of which mortgage lending constitutes a key pillar. Additional participant banks may join the program as the market develops. 	 - Ecobank Ghana Limited:  Ecobank Ghana is a subsidiary of Ecobank Transnational Incorporated (ETI)
column8: one of the largest banking franchises in Sub-Saharan Africa and head-quartered Lome
column9: Republic of Togo.  It is owned by a group of regional and international institutional investors as well as by individual businessmen.  ETI has fifteen subsidiaries strategically spread across West and Central Africa. EBG is a key subsidiary of the group and ranks among the three largest private sector banks in the country. EBGs focus has been on the corporate banking until recently
column10: but the bank is pursuing an aggressive strategy to develop its retail banking business. - Fidelity Bank:  Fidelity Bank was issued a universal banking license on June 28th 2006
column11: making Fidelity Bank Limited
column12: the 22nd bank to be licensed by the Bank of Ghana under the new Banking Act
column13: 2004 (Act 673).  The Bank is owned by its key executives
column14: in addition to a group of Ghanaian and foreign individual and institutional investors.  Among the institutional investors are ADB and SSNIT.  The Bank was formerly Fidelity Discount House
column15: the leading discount house in Ghana.  Fidelity Bank has two corporate affiliates: Fidelity Capital Partners Limited (FCPL)
column16: a venture capital and private equity fund management company
column17: and Fidelity Asset Management Limited (FAML)
column18: an asset management and investment management firm. - Ghana Home Loans:  Ghana Home Loans is a non-bank financial institution
column19: specializing in mortgage lending.  GHL opened its doors for business in June 2006 and aims to become the leading mortgage provider in the country. GHL was founded by a trio of experienced banking and investment executives.  They are backed by a strong shareholder group.  It addition to the core management team
column20: .the shareholder group is comprised of Standard Bank of South Africa
column21: FMO
column22: and Broad Cove Partners
column23: which is a US based investment firm. - Merchant Bank (Ghana) Limited:  Merchant Bank Ghana was established in 1972 as the first merchant banks in Ghana.  MBG converted to a universal bank in 2005 as part of an aggressive transformation plan to diversify its operations and to put the bank at the forefront of banking in Ghana.  In addition to corporate banking
column24: MBG is aggressively developing its business with small and medium-sized enterprises
column25: as well as retail customers.  The bank is owned by SSNIT
column26: the State Insurance Company
column27: and the Merchant Bank Staff Fund. - HFC Bank:  HFC Bank is currently the major provider of mortgage finance in the country.  The Bank was incorporated in 1990 as the first non-bank financial institution in Ghana specializing in housing finance.  It converted to a universal bank in 2003.  HFCs three largest shareholders are Union Bank of Nigeria
column28: SSNIT
column29: and Ghana Union Assurance Limited
column30: one of the leading privately owned insurance firms in the country.   	 - Social Security National Investment Trust:  The Social Security and National Insurance Trust (SSNIT) is a statutory public Trust charged with the administration of Ghana's National Pension Scheme.  The Trust is currently the largest non-bank financial institution in the country
column31: with an investment portfolio of about $1.2 billion.  It is estimated that SSNIT holds over 95 percent of the institutional investor funds in Ghana." column1: 24598 NA "Sampoerna:  A non-profit and philanthropic organization dedicated to improving the education sector in Indonesia

24630 NA "Ecobank Ghana Ltd (EBG): Ecobank Ghana (EBG) was incorporated in January 1989 as a private limited liability company.  Initially licensed to operate as a merchant bank by the Bank of Ghana
column2: it began operations in February 1990.  EBG has grown consistently over the years to become one of the leading banks in Ghana and a well-recognized brand in the Ghanaian banking industry.  EBG acquired a universal banking license in 2003 and has since expanded its geographical reach and broadened its scope of financial services.  It is now the fourth largest bank in Ghana with 8.4% of the market in terms of asset size and a network of 39 branches.  Its shares were listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange in July 2006.  EBG is an 87.47% owned subsidiary of Ecobank Transnational International (ETI)
column3: one of the largest banking franchises in Sub-Saharan Africa head-quartered in Lome
column4: Republic of Togo. ACCION International (ACCION): ACCION was established in 1961 and is currently one of the leading microfinance institutions in the world.  The mission of ACCION is to assist people working their way out of poverty by providing them with the necessary tools and training.  ACCION provides micro-loans
column5: business training and other financial services to people who start their own businesses.  ACCION has partnered with 35 microfinance institutions across Latin America
column6: the Caribbean
column7: Asia and Africa.  ACCION Investments in Microfinance (AIM) is an offshore investment company sponsored by ACCION International providing equity and quasi-equity financing to microfinance institutions (MFIs) worldwide.  Its investors include multi- and bi-lateral governmental entities as well as private investors from the United States and Europe.  ACCIONs shareholding in AIM is approx. 30%." NA "2009-06-30" "Not found or country name unknown" "EB-ACCION is set-up with paid-in capital of $3 million.  Ecobank and AIM invested $2.3 million (70%) and $1million (30%) respectively. The Bank of Ghana has announced that the minimum capital for Savings and Loans companies would increase from GHC 1.5million to between GHC 5 million and GHC 8 million
column8: so that Savings and Loans companies can be well capitalized to gain extensive market reach and have support when there are shocks in the system. IFCs participation will dilute the share ownership of Ecobank and raise the companys capital from GHC 3 million to GHC 8 million.  The additional capital will ensure that the company can support its planned growth strategy." 24668 "South Asia" "OCL India Limited (formerly known as Orissa Cement Limited) started operations in 1950 by setting up its first cement plant with a production capacity of 0.165 MTPA at Rajgangpur in the Indian state of Orissa (about 30 km from Rourkela). column2: which makes it one of the main producers in the eastern region of India.  The company also operates in the refractory and sponge iron businesses. OCL is the largest private sector producer for blast furnace bricks

column5: 000 tpy.  OCL is a part of the Dalmia Group of Companies. The Dalmia family holds 61.16% of the equity capital." 24733 NA "BP Plc: BP Plc. is one of the largest oil and gas groups in the world
column2: and Azerbaijan is one of the most important new exploration and production areas for the group. BP has been present in the country since 1992 and has become its leading foreign investor. BP is the operator of major projects in the Azerbaijan sector of the Caspian Sea including the Azeri-Chirag-Guneshli oil field
column3: Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan oil pipeline
column4: Shah Deniz gas fields
column5: and South Caucasus gas pipeline. The Enterprise Centre operated by BP on behalf of its oil and gas project venturers was launched in May 2002 and re-launched in September 2006 to help small and medium sized enterprises develop their business in support of major oil and gas developments in Azerbaijan. The goal of the Enterprise Centre is to make a significant contribution to the economic development of Azerbaijan by offering SMEs a full package of advice
column6: practical and financial support to help them secure work in both the oil and non-oil sectors. MFBA: MFBA was founded in 2002 by IFC
column7: EBRD
column8: Black Sea Trade and Development Bank (BSTDB)
column9: KfW and LFS Financial Services (LFS) as the first formal provider of financial services to SMEs in Azerbaijan.  The Banks goal is to provide a comprehensive set of financial services to micro and small business with limited access to finance
column10: using international best practice.  LFS is the projects technical partner in addition to being a shareholder. Since its creation in 2002
column11: MFBA has grown its total assets from $4.9 million equivalent to $45.2 million equivalent at the end of the third quarter of 2006
column12: while maintaining a high portfolio quality.  MFBA posted a profit of $851
column13: 000 in the first three quarters of 2006
column14: a significant increase over a profit of $147
column15: 000 in 2005." "2007-05-04" "2007-05-11" "Turkey" "The project will be structured as a risk sharing investment facility. The facility will have a total maturity of up to 8 years including a revolving period of up to 5 years. IFC will be the lender of record for the combined IFC/BP portion.  It is anticipated that each sub-loan under the facility will be funded by IFC
column16: BP and its partners and the Bank in a ratio of 40:40:20.   In addition to funding the facility
column17: each partner will contribute to the project in its area of expertise. IFC will assist in the design and management of the project based on its knowledge of the oil and gas and financial sectors
column18: and its experience with linkages program. BP will bring its knowledge of the oil and gas supply chain and its experience with Azerbaijani suppliers. BP will also make available technical support and training to borrowers
column19: through its Enterprise Centre in Baku. MFBA will bring its local knowledge of the banking sector and SMEs in the country
column20: and will operate the facility as the originator and servicing agent for the loans." "" "" "12" "" "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/9ec519da45e6d874852576ba000e2929?OpenDocument"

column1: 24800 "Latin America and the Caribbean" "ICA was established in 1947 as a family-owned company to focus on the construction of public sector infrastructure. column5: ICA and its shareholders have restructured the group in a rational manner to make a smooth transition from a family-owned group to a transparent and professionally managed publicly held group. column6: and direct shareholder of Infrainvest

column1: 25400 NA "The original formation of TUHF Section 21 came about through a pooling of resources of a number of stakeholders involved in inner city urban regeneration:  The National Housing Finance Corporation (NHFC)
column2: the National Urban and Reconstruction Agency (NURCHA) and the Inner City Housing Upgrading Trust (ICHUT) formed a joint venture to establish TUHF in June 2003.  As one of the founders
column3: ICHUT itself was formed as an NGO ten years ago
column4: and coupling with its two new partners
column5: transferred its loan book and retained earnings to the newly formed entity.  At inception
column6: TUHF Section 21 was the beneficiary of a capital base of approximately ZAR11 million ($1.6 million).  TUHF section 21s Board of Directors is drawn from its founding institutions as well as community associations such as the Banking Association of South Africa and the Johannesburg Housing Company.  Although it has a national mandate
column7: so far TUHF Section 21s initial focus has been on redlined areas of the Johannesburg city centre.  TUHF Section 21 chose this starting point for two reasons.  Firstly
column8: as the successor to ICHUT
column9: TUHF Section 21 could build on ICHUTs ten years of experience in lending to tenant-based and small private landlords in the Johannesburg inner city.  Secondly
column10: the experience of TUHF Section 21s staff and its Board of Directors was centered on Johannesburg." column1: 27196 NA "CRG Partners: CRG Partners is a leading middle market turnaround and restructuring firm in the US. The firm has a staff of 100 professionals in the US and Europe. CRG Partners and IFC have already worked together during the nineties in Poland in the privatization of three cement plants. CRG Capital: CRG Capital is the European subsidiary of CRG Partners and therefore benefits from their resources and turnaround experience. column1: 27313 NA "EAIF was initiated by the PIDG a multi-donor organization constituted in 2002. PIDGs objective is to encourage private infrastructure investment in developing countries that contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction. Since its establishment

column1: 28919 "Europe and Central Asia" "The Republic of Mariy El is one of 83 Regions in Russia with autonomous executive and legislative branches and budget.  It is located in the European part of Russia.  It is one of the smaller and less developed Regions in Russia with an area of 23
column2: 400 sq.km and a population of about 700
column3: 000.  The Republic is classified by IFC as one of the frontier regions in RF. Maryi Els industry remains rather underdeveloped and economy is dominated by traditional low-value-added sectors. While processing industry
column4: including oil refining and food processing contribute about 20% of the Republics GRP
column5: agriculture and forestry is the second largest sector (about 18% of GRP). Prior to the crisis the Republics GRP grew at an average rate of 13% during 2006-2008 (versus 8% growth in RFs GDP) and the Republic was one of the leading Regions in the Privolzhsky Federal District (consisting of 14 Regions) in terms of growth in direct investment
column6: SME output
column7: retail sector and average salary.  This trend continued until late 2008
column8: when industrial output grew 16% during the first nine months of the year relative to the same period in 2007 (6th highest growth rate among all Russian Regions).  However
column9: since October 2008
column10: the Republics economy and revenues have been negatively affected by the on-going crisis and its GRP is estimated to have contracted 2% in real terms in 2009. The budgetary performance of the Republic has been sound and was continuously improving until the on-set of the global economic crisis.  The Republics total revenues in 2009 decreased in real terms
column11: but increased in nominal terms relative to 2008 by 9% mostly due to an increase in federal transfers." column1: 30337 NA "EAIF was initiated by the PIDG a multi-donor organization constituted in 2002. PIDGs objective is to encourage private infrastructure investment in developing countries that contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction. Since its establishment
column2: the PIDG has developed project development facilities focused on improving project development and execution (InfraCo and DevCo) and project financing vehicles (GuarantCo and EAIF)
column3: aimed at addressing financial market failures that have created constraints to private investment in infrastructure service provision. GuarantCo which provides local currency guarantees to infrastructure projects in low-income countries to mitigate credit risks for local lenders is also managed by EAIFs fund manager.  PIDGs current members include: the UK Department for International Development (DFID)
column4: the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO)
column5: the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs (DGIS)
column6: the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (SIDA)
column7: the Austrian Development Agency (ADA)
column8: Irish Aid and the World Bank.  The PIDG members provide equity to EAIF through the PIDG Trust
column9: a vehicle for the development of PIDG programs and the ownership of its investment vehicles. EAIF is managed by Frontier Markets Fund Manager Limited (FMFML)
column10: also a special purpose company incorporated in Mauritius jointly owned by Standard Bank Group (70%)
column11: FMO (The Dutch Development Bank  18.4%) and Emerging Markets Partners (11.6%). FMFML in turn delegates most of the operational management to Frontier Markets Fund Managers (FMFM)
column12: a division of Standard Bank plc based in London and regulated by the U.K.s Financial Services Authority (FSA)." "2011-07-19" "2011-12-15" "Not found or country name unknown" "The total project cost of $150 million is equivalent to the net increase in the Fund size. column1: 30735 NA "UT Bank Limited was incorporated in April 1996 as Unique Trust Financial Services Ltd (UTFSL). The Bank of Ghana formally granted the company a license to operate as a non-bank financial institution and a certificate to commence business in April
column2: 1997. UTFSL listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) in November 2008 and by virtue of its acquisition of UT Bank in June 2010
column3: the Bank was reverse listed. The shareholder of reference is UT Holdings Limited. UT Banks primary sponsor is UT Holdings Limited a private company which holds 60% of the issued equity in the Bank. UT Holding is owned by 2 founding entrepreneurs Mr. Prince Amoabeng (CEO of UT Bank) and Mr. Joseph Nsonamaoh (Non-Executive Chairman of UT Bank). Of the remaining shareholding 10.3% is controlled by Investec Asset Management Public Funds
column4: 6.5% by Kura Capital and approximately 18.5 is % held by the general public none of whom control more than 5% of the Bank. UT Holdings has various other subsidiaries; these include UT Collections (Debt recovery services)
column5: UT Logistics (port clearance and warehousing services) and UT Properties (Real estate valuations and development consulting). The Holding Company has also set up lending institutions in Nigeria and Germany (targeting the Ghanaian Diaspora) expansion into Zambia and South Africa is at an advanced stage.  The focus segment of UT Bank is the SME market. Growth in the SME sector had been unpredicted in recent past with UT having experienced compound annual growth of over 50% over the past 5 years. It is anticipated that growth will continue at the similar levels for the medium term. The SME focus and strategy to successfully expand operations into the unbanked segment justify the development role for IFC; the proposed investment will therefore provide the risk capital to enable UT bank to achieve its reach targets in a sustainable manner." column2: Kalmykia is a key center of Buddhism in Russia." column1: 33642 "Latin America and the Caribbean" "CPFLR is a company focused on the development
column2: construction and operation of Renewable energy projects in Brazil. Its areas of operations include wind
column3: small hydro (less than 30 MWs of installed capacity) and biomass projects. Going forward it also plans to expand into solar as this becomes viable in Brazil. Since the merger
column4: CPFLR has been growing its operations and has 1.15 GW of operating capacity (556 MW in wind
column5: 326 MW in SHP and 270MW in biomass) and 582 MWs under construction
column6: besides a strong pipeline of 3.8 GWs of projects under development. This makes it the leading player in the Renewable energy market in Brazil. Prior to the listing

column8: being the leader in energy distribution and commercialization
column9: and the third largest utility in the Country. It operates in both the regulated and the free markets. CPFL is listed in BOVESPAs Novo Mercado and the New York Stock Exchange NYSE (through ADR III).  In 2013
column10: CPFL Energia completed eight years of its dual IPO and participation in BOVESPAs Sustainability Index (ISE). column4: which can use its technology and service to add secure and convenient Internet connectivity to their smart home or wearable devices.  OEMs already place computer chips in their products and Ayla embeds its software on those chips which then allow end-users to quickly

column6: Phillip Chang
column7: Adrian Caceres
column8: and Professor Tom Lee of Stanford University
column9: with the goal of building out a seamless cloud-based service to link machines and consumer products to the Internet where end-users can remotely control the device using an application on their smartphone.  The four co-founders currently own approximately 40% of the Company

column12: own 20% each
column13: with the remaining 20% held by employees
column14: angel investors

column18: which was successfully sold in 2010
column19: was also a pioneer in providing connectivity and Friedman and Chang were responsible for business development in North America and Europe
column20: and Asia-Pacific

column1: 35682 "Europe and Central Asia" "With around 1.9 million inhabitants in 2010 (latest UNDP data)
column2: Bucharest is the largest Romanian municipality and the center of the Romanian economy and industry. Following the transition to free market in the 1990s

column4: including information & communications technology
column5: telecommunication
column6: services
column7: as well as the banking sector. The city government is headed by Mayor Sorin Oprescu. Decisions are approved and discussed by the capital's General Council made up of 55 elected councilors. Furthermore
column8: the city is divided into six administrative sectors
column9: each of which has their own 27-seat sectoral council
column10: town hall and mayor. The powers of the local government over a certain area are therefore shared both by the Bucharest Municipality and the local sectoral councils with little or no overlapping of authority. The general rule is that the main Capital Municipality is responsible for citywide utilities and the overall transport system
column11: while sectoral town halls manage the contact between individuals and the local government
column12: secondary streets and parks maintenance
column13: schools administration and cleaning services. The Municipality of Bucharest has an annual budget of RON 3.2 billion and an operating margin of 32% (2013)." column1: 35877 "Sub-Saharan Africa" "Seven Energy currently has two core areas of operation in the South East and North West onshore Niger Delta. The South East Niger Delta has significant discovered but undeveloped gas fields
column2: with some installed gas demand and significant growth potential
column3: but very limited gas processing and distribution infrastructure. The North West Niger Delta is characterized by mature oil and gas fields
column4: with pipeline infrastructure in place
column5: but with significant additional undeveloped gas reserves and a shortage of gas processing capacity.  Seven Energys strategy has been to grow its business primarily through (i) exploiting its existing asset base
column6: (ii) establishing gas pipelines
column7: processing
column8: and transportation systems within its areas of operation through which it can transport production to the expanding Nigerian domestic gas and power market
column9: (iii) negotiating supply agreements with upstream gas producers
column10: (iv) reaching sales agreements with power and industrial producers
column11: and (v) completing strategic acquisitions of attractive oil and gas assets. The Companys expansion plan for the next few years is to strengthen its unique position as a key midstream player in the south-eastern part of Nigeria. This plan includes both upstream and midstream oil and gas activities. Seven Energy was founded by a group of Nigerian investors and international executives in 2004. It benefits from a strong management team experienced in upstream and midstream
column12: as well as gas to power generation
column13: under the leadership of CEO Phillip Ihenacho. As of May 31
column15: three shareholders held greater than 10% of Sevens shares: Temasek Holdings
column16: Petrofac Limited
column17: and Capital Group Private Markets. IFC and AMC ALAC Fund held 7.7% and 3.1%
column18: respectively." "2014-09-26" "2014-10-01" "Not found or country name unknown" "The proposed investment consists of an IFC investment of up to $50 million in Seven Energys inaugural bond issue. The bond proceeds will be used

column1: 36281 "Latin America and the Caribbean" "ECG is an international specialty finance company with operations in eight countries. Its subsidiaries purchase portfolios of consumer receivables and acquire delinquent property tax debt from major banks
column2: credit unions
column3: utility providers
column4: and municipalities
column5: and partner with individuals as they repay their obligations and work toward financial recovery. ECGs subsidiaries include Midland Credit Management
column6: which purchases and services unsecured consumer debt in the US; Propel Financial Services
column7: which assists property owners delinquent on their property taxes in the US; Grove Capital Management
column8: Cabot Credit Management and Marlin Financial Services
column9: which acquire and service consumer debt in the United Kingdom
column10: Ireland and Spain; and Refinancia
column11: which services distressed consumer debt in Colombia and Peru. ECGs success is fueled by its demonstrated commitment to conducting business ethically and in ways that support consumers financial recovery
column12: sophisticated and widespread use of analytics
column13: significant investments in data and behavioral science
column14: and cost advantages provided by its highly efficient operating model and proven investment strategy. In 2011
column15: ECG and Midland Credit Management unveiled the industrys first and only Consumer Bill of Rights
column16: which codifies the companys commitment to respectful consumer treatment. Some of the tenets of the Consumer Bill of Rights include contacting consumers in a timely and effective manner
column17: resolving accounts quickly and honestly
column18: forgiveness of debt in times of hardship
column19: collection practices that preserve dignity
column20: and fair and reasonable use of litigation. ECGs Consumer Credit Research Institute
column21: which partners with leading universities and non-profit organizations
column22: is dedicated to understanding financially distressed consumer behavior so that the company can create and manage programs that provide significant
column23: measurable benefits to consumers. CCRI explores the ways in which consumers get into financial trouble and looks for ways to break the cycle of chronic debt that can lead to financial distress. CCRI is an industry-leading effort to differentiate and describe an important and often neglected consumer segment
column24: and hopes to advance thinking in the areas of public policy
column25: financial education and business operations. Headquartered in San Diego
column26: California

column28: the S&P SmallCap 600

column31: TX; St. Cloud

column6: Helion Ventures
column7: Zodius Capital and Bessemer Venture Partners." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "IFC proposes to invest equity of up to US$25 million in the Company
column8: as part of its ongoing fundraising." 547669 "East Asia and the Pacific" "Shenzhen PhasCon Technologies Co. Ltd (or PhasCon) was founded in 2001 and its main business at that time was the R&D of energy efficiency technologies and the manufacturing of energy-saving products.  In 2003
column2: PhasCon became a Foreign Joint Venture Company with a Canadian investors participation in both financial investment and landfill gas (LFG) collection and utilization technology transfer to focus on LFG projects.  PhasCon is registered as a Sino-Canadian joint venture company
column3: 75% of which is owned by the Chinese partner
column4: Dr. YU Yuanqi
column5: and 25% of which is owned by the Canadian partner
column6: Mr. Gerry Hamaliuk.  PhasCon will be the full and direct owner of the Huizhou and Huiyang LFGTE projects
column7: and will own 80% of the Dalian LFGTE project through Dalian PhasCon Technologies Co.
column8: Ltd.
column9: which was established exclusively own the project in Dalian.  PhasCon is the companys main shareholder and owns 80% of the total shares.  The remaining 20% are owned by two employees of the Dalian subsidiary company
column10: Mr. LI Chengbin and Ms. LUO Mei.   PhasCon won a Chinese National Enterprise New Record Award in 2002 on its energy efficiency technology for its A/C motor and an UNIDO Blue Sky award for its work on Meizhou Landfill Gas Recovery as Power Project
column11: which has been operating since 2006 at Meizhou in Guangdong Province
column12: China." NA NA "China" "PhasCon estimates that the capital cost of the three LFG projects will be $5.0 million and will generate approximately 2.0 million CERs during the 2008-2012 period.  INCaF intends to provide an advance payment of $1.9 million against the purchase of CERs from the project.  The total value of the INCaF purchase contract is expected to be in the range of $21 - $28 million payable in installments on delivery of CERs (generated through to the end of 2012) to the CDM registry account of the Netherlands." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/74fe78c088c18601852576ba000e2b17?OpenDocument http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/e194e5fe6d487da2852576ba000e2b1e?OpenDocument"

column1: 556565 NA "Beijing Deqingyuan Agricultural Technology Company
column2: Ltd. (Deqingyuan or DQY) is a privately held company established in May 2002 by Tianjin Baodi Agriculture Technology Inc. and Beijing Deqingyuan Technology Company
column3: which had been established only two years earlier by Mr. Zhong Kaimin
column4: now CEO of DQY
column5: and Ms. Xia Fang.  Zhong and Xia assembled a team which developed the technological know-how to produce high-quality eggs and then
column6: with other investors
column7: found DQY to produce them.  Mr. Zhong holds an engineering master degree and an MBA.  Between 1984 and 2001
column8: Mr. Zhong worked for the Central government in Beijing where he became aware of the health
column9: safety and environmental issues of the egg industry and saw the potential for producing high quality eggs.  Mr. Zhong left the government in 2002 and devoted himself to building the company into a leading high quality egg producer in China. IFC made an investment in DQY in 2005 and a number of other individual and corporate investors invested in DQY since its founding.  Current shareholders and their respective ownership shares are as follows: - IFC 8% - Global Environment Fund
column10: a Washington
column11: DC-based private equity group 16% - two Hong Kong Chinese investment groups
column12: Innobiz Agricultural Ltd. and Capital Today
column14: respectively - Beijing Deqingyuan Technology Company 28% - Shanghai Yibei Management Consulting 8% - six natural persons 15%" NA NA "China" "The total cost for the Biogas Project is approximately $6.5 million and is being financed by Deqingyuans internal cash flow and loan from Industrial Bank
column15: a local Chinese bank.  Industrial Bank is a participant in the IFC/GEF Chinese Utility Energy Efficiency (CHUEE) Program that is cooperating with Chinese banks to offer partial guarantees to portfolios of loans made to renewable energy and energy efficiency projects in China." column1: 559586 NA "ING Bank is the counterparty for the sale of Emission Reduction Units to IFC. ING Bank is a subsidiary of ING Groep N.V. (ING). ING was founded in 1991 by a merger between insurance company Nationale-Nederlanden and banking company NMB Postbank Group into Internationale Nederlanden Group - soon abbreviated to I-N-G. The company followed suit by changing the statutory name to ING Groep N.V. ING is one of the world's largest financial services companies
column2: offering banking
column3: insurance and asset management services.   The authorized capital of ING Group is made up of ordinary shares
column4: preference shares and cumulative preference shares. As of year-end 2006
column5: ING had 2.2 billion outstanding depositary receipts for ordinary shares. Based on information provided by custodians
column6: as of 2006
column7: 33% of INGs shareholders were based in UK followed by 31% in the Benelux region and 12% in USA and Canada. Under the Dutch Act on the Disclosure of Significant Holdings in Listed Companies
column8: two holders of depositary receipts with a stake
column9: or potential stake
column10: of between 5% and 10% in ING Group were known as of 25 April 2006. They were ABN Amro and Fortis Utrecht." NA NA "Netherlands" "IFC
column11: acting as Trustee of the Government of the Netherlands
column12: will purchase Emission Reduction Units and possibly a limited quantity of Assigned Amount Units from ING Bank N.V. for Euro 10 million." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/01b1538a69a0ef2d852579c7006420e2?OpenDocument"

column1: 559785 "Middle East and North Africa" "The Saudi German Yemen Hospital (SGH)
column2: an existing IFC client in Sanaa
column3: Yemen
column4: initiated this program based on its interest in providing antenatal and maternal care services to women from poorer and underserved communities in Sanaa. The Saudi German Hospitals Group began its operations in 1998 and is one of the largest private for profit healthcare providers in the Middle East. It currently operates five hospitals in the MENA region and is about to establish a new hospital in Cairo
column5: Egypt.  University of Science and Technology Hospital (USTH) joined SGH in this program. USTH is a 144 bed private teaching hospital. It includes a full service hospital and a medical residence for students at the UST medical school.  It was established in March 2005 to improve access to quality healthcare services and health professionals in Sanaa.  It is the second largest private hospital in Sanaa in terms of number of beds available. It is the first private hospital which is affiliated to a university medical school." NA NA "Yemen" "The total project cost is estimated at $7.6million and GPOBA will subsidize approximately 89% of the total cost." column1: 564149 NA "The Global Environment Facility (GEF) is the main sponsor of the GEF Earth Fund.  In June 2006
column2: the GEF Council
column3: having reviewed the GEF Strategy to Enhance Engagement with the Private Sector
column4: supported the further development of a proposal to enhance financing through a public-private sector partnership.  An operational road map for implementation of the GEF Public Private Partnership Initiative (PPP) was subsequently proposed to and approved by the Council in June 2007.  The GEF Earth Fund is the re-named GEF Public Private Partnership approved last year by the GEF Council.   IFC will have three functions in The Earth Fund:  First
column5: IFC will act as the Executing Agency of the Earth Fund.  Second
column6: IFC will manage the GEF Earth Fund
column7: as directed by the Council and GEF CEO.  In this role
column8: the Trustee Management & Administration team at IFC would support the administration of the trust fund established for the Earth Fund
column9: including executing grant agreements with Agencies approved for Platforms
column10: managing donor agreements to the Earth Fund
column11: and general administration of the GEF Earth Fund trust fund. Ex officio
column12: IFC would be a member of the Earth Fund Board.  Finally
column13: IFC will pilot the implementation of the first of several platforms/programs (the IFC Earth Fund Platform) and
column14: in setting up and implementing the platform
column15: IFC would devise and test operational procedures and policies that could then subsequently be used by other GEF implementing agencies when they take on the implementation of their own Earth Fund Platform." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "The GEF Earth Fund will have an initial capitalization of $50M from the GEF.  IFC will contribute an initial $10M to an IFC Platform within the GEF Earth Fund.  The GEF Earth Fund will have a minimum of 1:3 leverage (GEF funds: other funds)
column16: and will fund a minimum of $200M in projects." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/b25e2397e520bf90852576ba000e2c38?OpenDocument"

column1: 564150 NA "The IFC Earth Fund platform is a platform under the GEF Earth Fund.  The GEF has allocated $50M to the GEF Earth Fund
column2: and of this
column3: the IFC Earth Fund platform will receive $30M.  IFC will contribute $10M from FMTAAS funding for this project." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "The IFC Earth Fund Platform will have an initial capitalization of $40M:  $30M from the GEF Earth Fund
column4: and $10M from the IFC FMTAAS.  The IFC may attract additional contributions for the Platform from interested donors and the private sector.    These funds will be deployed into a portfolio of sub-projects which will support technical assistance
column5: capacity building and investments in projects that are in line with the strategic priorities of the GEF in the areas of Climate Change and Biodiversity." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/448a93d83dfc5f7a852576ba000e2c37?OpenDocument"

column1: 567207 NA "Moser Baer Clean Energy Limited
column2: engaged in Solar Farm development intends to implement Solar PV Power Project in India and is in the process of developing PV power generation projects of 5 MW each through SIIPL. SIIPL is implementing the first 5 MW Solar PV Power Project at Sivaganga district in Tamil Nadu." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "The total cost of the project is about $20 million. Out of this
column3: $6 million would be funded through equity contributed by Moser Baer Projects Pvt. Ltd. IFC has been requested to provide financial support of $4 million to the project. The balance $10 million would be financed through local financial institutions / banks." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/bd4aeac1c2d6a0a7852576ba000e2daf?OpenDocument"

column1: 574447 NA "The Project will support a number of different sponsors. These will be identified and disclosed under individual investment agreements." NA NA "Not found or country name unknown" "The Project is co-financed by the Finnish Ministry of Employment and the Economy
column2: the Finnish Ministry for Foreign Affairs
column3: and by the Global Environemtal Facility (GEF). This SPI covers only the GEF co-financing piece of $4.7 million
column4: which
column5: in turn
column6: consists of two components: (1) an advisory component of $1.3 million and (2) an investment component of $3.4 million indented to be channeled through a risk-sharing vehicle that the Project will be developing jointly with the IFC Investment department. The amount of IFC invesment is to be determinted but notionally is anticipated to be $50 million over a five-year period. These investments will be made through financial institutions for further on-lending to finance  energy efficient renovations of multi-family buildings in Russia." NA NA NA NA "http://ifcextapps.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/651aeb16abd09c1f8525797d006976ba/f04a726ea93fa90b85257801007593d9?OpenDocument"

column5: Mercators shareholding was as follows: - Banka Koper (acting on behalf of financial holding Istrabenz) (15.0%); - Slovenian Compensation Fund (SOD) (13.78%); - corporations and other legal entities (36.9%); - investment funds (10.1%); and - individuals (24.25%)."
